awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Reconstructing Spatiotemporal Climatic Patterns for Northeastern Canada
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project generally aims to generate new tree-ring data from Blue Intensity (BI is proposed as a direct proxy for density) and three anatomical measurements of cell number (CN), lumen diameter (LD) and cell wall thickness (CWT) all of which have proposed links to climate.  New tree-ring samples will be collected along a latitudinal transect to fill a large spatial gap in paleoclimatic data and potentially allow the inference of spatial shifts and patterns in climatic variability over the past several centuries. 

This transect extends from southern, coastal to near-coastal sites in Newfoundland and southeastern Labrador to the Mealy Mountains Park and Reserve in central Labrador, and to latitudinal treeline near Napaktok Fjord north of Nain and outlier sites just to the north. These new collections will be used to update existing datasets and better quantify past climate and environmental variability across space and time and extend the record into the Medieval Climate Anomaly.

The climate of Labrador and Newfoundland is largely determined by the prevailing western North Atlantic's atmosphere-ocean dynamics including effects of the Labrador Sea, a key component of the Earth's thermohaline circulation system.  Other influences include dominant climate modes such as the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO).  Reconstructions of northwest Atlantic sector sea surface temperatures (SST), land temperature, sea-ice extent and hydroclimate, as well as analyses of instrumental and reanalysis data, could potentially improve the current knowledge of climate change in this highly dynamic region. 

The overarching research questions are: 1) What are the underlying causes and patterns of long-term climate variability across the region? 2) How does the climate of the anthropogenic period compare with prior centuries?

This project involves the potential for a unique and potentially transformative analytical technique (i.e., Blue Intensity) for exploring climate processes in circumpolar regions. There is also outreach to Labrador's northernmost village of Nain, where communities must cope with severe socioeconomic challenges amid recent climatic extremes.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

With this project we sought to expand upon our prior tree ring work from Labrador, where we used ring width and some maximum latewood density data (MXD, from soft x-ray) to analyze past temperature variability from this important region of the North Atlantic. We conducted one field expedition to northern Labrador in August of 2017, where we obtained 7 new site collections to augment the existing tree ring record and expand coverage. We experienced several setbacks, most notably due to Covid restrictions on travel, that stymied our efforts to conduct further collections in the central and southern regions of Labrador. We therefore took the opportunity to work with a collection of birch cores from southern Greenland taken by PI Buckley in 1999. From these cores we produced the first record of δ18O from Greenland tree rings and demonstrated their utility as a climate proxy for regional temperature and the North Atlantic Oscillation. At the outset we conducted a pilot study of a sub-sample of Labrador spruce cores from our sample archives for Blue Intensity (BI), which serves as an indirect measure of density. The BI method takes advantage of lignin's propensity to absorb blue light, such that the degree of BI reflected from scanned images is a measure of the lignin content of the tracheid cells, and hence a proxy for density. We conducted this experiment on cores from 18 Labrador spruce trees from which we had ring width and MXD data already generated, so that our comparison used the exact same samples. Our method worked on this pilot, exhibiting very strong linkages to regional climate (temperature), with nearly the same magnitude as density from MXD, and showing a high degree of correlation between MXD and latewood BI - reinforcing the use of BI as a proxy for density. While the MXD variable exhibits a slightly more robust correlation with temperature over the Labrador Peninsula, the sign and strength are nearly identical for BI. Ring width, on the other hand, exhibits very little in the way of correlation with regional temperature, but as we demonstrate in our publication, RW is useful for analyzing broad scale climate dynamics across the North Atlantic sector. Our regional BI record shows very strong correlation with regional climate, as expected, and coupled with the RW records provide a robust proxy network for the study of North Atlantic climate variability.

 

Broader Impacts

Project PIs and our surrogates presented results at several international conferences, and published two key papers from this project. We provided new tree-ring records from along a spatial transect of the Labrador region, as well as from southern Greenland, that will be used to yield high-resolution, well-calibrated and verified dendroclimatic reconstructions of past climate variability from annual to multidecadal and centennial time scales. We also developed a large master record of Labrador regional density via the Blue Intensity (BI) method, and southern Greenland temperature via a δ18O tree rings series from Greenland. These data will be compared to model simulation output and other proxy records and made available to the greater community. This project contributed to a broad understanding of the Arctic system and its multiple components. Results from this project have been presented at the LDEO biennial public Open House, and through seminars and presentations at various institutions and conferences, with international peer-review publications, conference proceedings and presentations and student reports and theses, and archived in appropriate venues and on our websites. All data will be provided to the scientific community through the National Geophysical Data Center (NGDC) and International Tree-Ring Data Bank (ITRDB). Several students, research assistants and postdoctoral fellows were mentored at WHOI and at LDEO throughout the course of this project.
